variant.question:
Refer to GSPRM Jeppesen Approach Plate ALICANTE (11-2) ILS Y RWY 10.
During the approach to RWY 10 a sudden change in wind direction, resulting in a tail-wind, does not permit you carry out your landing to RWY 10.
Which of the following options is the correct action?

options.text: Carry out the Missed Approach procedure for RWY 10 and circle to the South to land on RWY 28
Continue the Approach to RWY 10 and level at the Circle to Land MDA before circling to the North of the aerodrome to land on RWY 28.
Carry out the Missed Approach procedure for RWY 10 and circle to the North to land on RWY 28

variant.question:
Refer to Jeppesen GSPRM Training Route Manual ALICANTE 11-2.  
  You are arriving to the airport, but when you are about to land, the tailwind changes above limits. What do you do?

options.text: Carry out missed approach and circle South of the airport

variant.question:
Refer to GSPRM Jeppesen ALICANTE, Approach plate 13-1, VOR Z Rwy 10.
You are part of a fully qualified crew and carrying out the VOR Z  procedure to Rwy 10 in CAVOK conditions when ATC informs you of a runway change due to a change in wind direction.  Can you continue the approach and circle to land?

options.text: Yes, but not North of the Rwy.
No, you must overshoot and commence a full approach to the opposite runway

variant.question: An aerodrome has an ILS approach to runway 20 with a decision altitude of 250 feet. If the aerodrome elevation is 110 feet, what is the category of approach?

A pilot is planning a flight for 4th of December 2019 and checks the NOTAMs for his/her destination aerodrome Hamburg (EDDH). What is the relevance of the following NOTAM for the time from 1315Z to 1625Z?Q)EDWW/QGAAU/I/NBO/A/000/999/5338N00959E030 
 A)EDDH 
 B)1912041315 
 C)1912041625 
 E)EGNOS IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR LPV

options.text: SBAS will NOT be available at Hamburg to use LPV minima.
ABAS will NOT be available at Hamburg to use LPV minima.
ABAS will NOT be available to aircraft on any approaches to Hamburg.
SBAS outage prevents 3D RNAV approaches to Hamburg.

variant.question:
Which of the following circumstances would be considered suitable for fuel tankering?

1. The estimated landing mass is equal to the maximum landing mass.2. The weather at the destination is below landing minima.3. Unable to climb to the Minimum Obstacle Clearance Altitude (MOCA) should an engine fail.4. There is no fuel available at the destination aerodrome.

When a destination alternate is only available at a greater distance from the planned destination and it cannot be reached after first flying to the destination, a fuel planning procedure is available for operators which allows to legally select this aerodrome as an alternate nonetheless. This procedure is called:

Consider an IFR flight with a departure aerodrome called "DEP" and a destination aerodrome called "DEST" and a decision point called "DP", since the decision point procedure has to be used.

There is also a suitable aerodrome for refuelling, called aerodrome "REF". The pilot has calculated a trip fuel from DEP to DEST so the contingency will be at least:

Given the following information:DOM: 4 565 kg 
 Traffic load: 2 590 kg 
 Remaining usable fuel: 990 kg 
 Remaining trip fuel to destination: 410 kg 
 Alternate fuel: 235 kg 
 Final reserve fuel: 275 kgCalculate the revised estimated landing mass at the destination aerodrome.

A pilot is preparing a commercial flight but during the planning phase the latest weather update at the destination aerodrome leads to a change of the runway which in turn results to a more time consuming arrival section. What will happen to the planned trip fuel?

options.text: It has to be updated correspondingly.
The pilot could update the trip fuel, but he/she does not have to update the contingency fuel because it covers such changes during the planning phase.
It will not change because the arrival fuel consists of a fixed quantity.
It will not change because it is not part of the arrival procedure.

variant.question:
A pilot is preparing a commercial flight but during the planning phase the latest weather update at the destination aerodrome leads to a change of the runway which in turn results to a more time consuming arrival section.
What will happen to the planned trip fuel?

options.text: It has to be updated correspondingly.
The pilot could update the trip fuel, but he/she does not have to update the contingency fuel because it covers such changes during the planning phase.
It will not change because it is not part of the arrival procedure.
It will not change because the arrival fuel consists of a fixed quantity.

If the flight is performed as planned, the estimated Landing Mass at the destination airport should be:
When planning a Commercial Air Transport flight to an isolated aerodrome destination, the last possible point of diversion to any available En Route Alternate ERA aerodrome should be used as the

options.text: En Route Alternate ERA diversion point.

variant.question: A pilot has planned a flight but the destination reports a weather phenomenon which induced the pilot to update his/her fuel log. Which of the following phenomena does this refer to (most likely)?

A pilot has planned a flight but the destination reports a weather phenomenon which induced the pilot to update his/her the fuel log. Which of the following phenomena does this refer to (most likely)?
The Commercial Air Transport flight shall be conducted so that the expected usable remaining fuel on arrival at the destination aerodrome is NOT less than the sum of the

options.text: Alternate Fuel and the Final Reserve Fuel.
Alternate Fuel and the Contingency Fuel.
Contingency Fuel and the Final Reserve Fuel.
Alternate Fuel, Contingency Fuel and the Final Reserve Fuel.

variant.question: The commander is responsible for the fuel. What is true regarding a diversion of a commercial flight?

options.text: The remaining fuel should be at least the same amount as the required fuel to reach an aerodrome where a safe landing can be made, with final reserve fuel remaining.

The remaining fuel should be at least the same as the amount which is required to reach at least two different aerodromes where a safe landing can be made. One of them can be the aerodrome of departure.
A diversion is an unplanned event so the commander is not responsible concerning this amount of fuel.
The remaining fuel should be at least the same amount as the required fuel to return to the aerodrome of departure.

variant.question:
Given the following information, find the Final Reserve Fuel for a Commercial Air Transport flight with a twin-jet aeroplane to a destination (DEST) having one destination alternate (ALTN) required
 Estimated Landing Mass at DEST 60000 kg 

Alternate Fuel 3000 kg 

DEST elevation 0 ft
  ALTN elevation 3500 ft
  ISA conditions

Calculate the allowed mass for take-off, given the following data for a Medium-Range Jet Transport Aeroplane(MRJT).

Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM): 61688 kgMaximum Take-Off Mass (MTOM): 66990 kgMaximum Landing Mass (MLM): 65317 kgPerformance limited Take-Off Mass (TOM): 64900 kgPerformance limited Landing Mass (LM): 67300 kgTrip Fuel: 3800 kgBlock Fuel: 6000 kg

A pilot has planned the fuel consumption for a trip including the approach. Before departure, when the weather is assessed, the pilot notices that a long approach in another direction has to be made due to weather conditions. What is the best action that should be taken?

options.text: Delay the flight until the weather conditions are improved.
No need to carry extra fuel since 5 % contingency fuel is intended to be used for situations like this.

variant.question:
Most Commercial Air Transport flights are planned in such a way that they include an En-Route Alternate (ERA) aerodrome. Use the data below and choose the correct statement regarding Alternate Fuel.
ERA aerodrome for 3 % contingency fuel: LPFR
Destination aerodrome: DESA
Destination alternate aerodrome: ALTB

options.text: The fuel for a diversion to LPFR is included in the Trip Fuel. Alternate Fuel must be sufficient to fly from DESA to ALTB.
Alternate Fuel must be sufficient to fly from a point en-roure to LPFR and then from DESA to ALTB, so it includes the flight time to all alternate aerodromes.
Alternate Fuel must be sufficient to fly from a LPFR to DESLA in the event of an en-route diversion to LPFR and then sufficient to fly from DESLA to ALTB.
Alternate Fuel must be sufficient to fly from a DESLA to LPFR or from DESLA to ALTB, whichever requires the greater amount of fuel.

variant.question: How is assumed the mass of the aircraft at destination?

options.text: Zero fuel mass, alternate, final reserve fuel, contingency.
Zero fuel mass, final reserve fuel, contingency.
Zero fuel mass, alternate, final reserve fuel.

variant.question: How is the mass of the aircraft at destination assumed?

options.text: Zero fuel mass, alternate, final reserve fuel, contingency.
Zero fuel mass, final reserve fuel, contingency.
Zero fuel mass, alternate, final reserve fuel.

You are planning an IFR flight from A to B, where the total distance is 933 NM. You chose an en-route alternate aerodrome for this flight, which is located a couple of NM beside your intended track line, at a distance of 402.4 NM from the destination airport. What is correct regarding the contingency fuel on this flight, for an operator having no specific fuel monitoring system?

options.text: Contingency fuel should be no less than 3% of the total trip fuel.
Contingency fuel fuel should be no less than what is required to fly fορ 30 minutes at 1 500 ft AGL above the destination aerodrome.
Contingency fuel should be no less than what is required to fly for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft AGL above the destination aerodrome.
Contingency fuel should be no less than 5% of the total trip fuel.

A pilot is planning a flight on the 23rd May, and plans to fly over the location mentioned below at 1400. The maximum altitude the flight will operate at is 1500 f. t
Is the following NOTAM likely to be a factor for the flight? EGPX/QRDCA/IV/BO/W/000/021/5736N00403W002 DANGER AREA D7025 ACTIVATED LOWER SFC UPPER 2100FT AMSL FROM 22 MAY 1500 TO 30 MAY 2259

options.text: Yes, the information in the NOTAM is a factor.
Only under VFR, as airways are excluded from the effects of such notifications.
No, the NOTAM is not a factor.
Yes, the NOTAM is a factor but only if no flight plan has been filed.

variant.question:
The following is an extract from a NOTAM briefing for the planned aerodrome of destination of an IFR flight.  B) FROM: 13/02/01 11:00 C) TO: 13/02/01 12:00  E) NDB CLB 433KHZ U/S -
Which of the following statements is completely correct?

options.text: The ‘CLB’ navigation facility, a non-directional beacon, will be out of service for one hour on the 1 February 2013.

The ‘CLB’ NDB is unserviceable between 11:00 and 12:00 on 13 February and military aircraft able to transmit and receive voice communications on 433 kHz should also note that this frequency will be unguarded for the same time period.
Navigation facilities ‘NDB’ and ‘CLB’, both transmitting on 433 kHz, are unavailable for use between 11:00 and 12:00 on the morning of 13 February.

Aircraft with a navigational data base should be aware that, at the destination airfield (IATA identifier ‘CLB’), the frequency band 433 kHz will be out of service from 11:00 to 12:00 on 1 February 2013.

Q) EDGG/QIXLT/I /BO /A /000/999/5002N00834E005 
A) EDDF 
B) 1310240921 
C) PERM 
E) ILS 25C LO, IDENT FR, 297KHZ, RANGE LIMITED TO 10NM.

Given the following NOTAM, is it possible to fly from EUAD on the 1st March?

Q EGTT/QAZCD/IV/NBO/AE/000/022/5456N00249W002 A EUAD B FROM: 16/02/04 09:00C TO: 16/03/05 18:00 E AERODROME ATZ DEACTIVATED. ATS NOT AVBL. AD NOT AVBL TO ACFT EXCEPT WITH OUT OF HOURS PERMISSION. IAP NOT AVBL

options.text: Yes, if permission is obtained to fly out of hours.
Yes, Commercial Air Transport flights are insured for such situations.
No, the airfield is out of commission between the 4th of February and the 5th of March.
No, the trip must be delayed until after 18:00 on the 5th March.

variant.question: The following NOTAM is given: MADRID APPROACH FRQ CHNG FROM 118.400 TO CH 118.405 READ INSTEAD. What does it mean?

options.text: In order to read frequency 118.400 MHz you have to set 118.405 MHz.
Madrid changed frequency from 118.400 MHz to CHANNEL 118.400 MHz.
Madrid is using frequency 118.400 MHz and 118.405 MHz.
Madrid changed frequency from 118.405 MHz to 118.400 MHz.

variant.question:
What changes apply to the missed approach procedure on runway 24?
>>> EDDK KOLN/BONN<<< DUE TO MAINT OF WYP VOR THE FLW CHANGES TO APCH AND MISSED APCH PROC OCCUR: RWY 14L: AMEND CONVENTIONAL MISSED APCH TO READ: CLIMB STRAIGHT AHEAD **3000**, WHEN PASSING 2 000 OR 2.8 DME KBO, WHICHEVER IS LATER, LT DIRECT TO WYP INT. RWY 24: AMEND CONVENTIONAL MISSED APCH TO READ: CLIMB STRAIGHT AHEAD TO **2100** FT MSL OR 3.5 DME KBO, WHICHEVER IS LATER, RT DIRECT TO WYP INT CLIMBING **5000FT** MSL. REF AD 2 EDDK 4-2-1, 4-4-1, 4-2-2, 4-4-2, 4-6-2 AND 4-6-4 ALL DATED 10 DEC **2015**.: NOTAM ED/ **A0709**/16 ILS OUTER MARKER RWY 24: CHECK DME READING ADDITIONALLY &MARKER NOT REMOTE CONTROLLED.: NOTAM ED/**A0699**/16 >>> END OF BULLETIN<<<

options.text: CLIMB STRAIGHT AHEAD TO 2100 FT MSL OR 3.5 DME KBO, WHICHEVER IS LATER.
CHECK DME READING ADDITIONALLY MARKER NOT REMOTE CONTROLLED
COMPLY WITH CONVENTIONAL MISSED APCH AS READ.
WHEN PASSING 2000 OR 2.8 DME KBO, WHICHEVER IS LATER, LT DIRECT TO WYP INT.

variant.question: An aeroplane is flying from New York to London and there is a headwind. Where is the PSR in this case? (The aircraft has just enough endurance for the city pair.)

options.text: It is not possible to make an assumption without having specific data.
PSR always remains in the middle (between New York and London).

variant.question:
Pre-flight briefing for flights away from the vicinity of an aerodrome and all IFR flights shall include which of the following?
 
1) A meteorological brief.
 
2) A consideration of the fuel requirements.
 
3) Alternative actions if the flight cannot be completed as planned.

options.text: all of the above are recommended but not mandatory.

During the pre-flight planning of a Commercial Air Transport transport operation, the flight crew is reviewing the serviceability of the GNSS. The NOTAM announces fluctuations of the signal reception in the destination area at the time of arrival. Normally they fly an RNP approach at the destination. For this particular flight, the best decision is to....

options.text: cancel the flight and re-schedule it when the GNSS signal reception is fully functioning as an RNP approach must be flown.
postpone the flight because the lack of GNSS achievability is very dangerous.
carry on with the flight as there are two GPS receivers on board, which can compensate for signal fluctuation.
prepare another approach based on radio navigation aids, as a back-up in case the GNSS signal is lost in flight.

variant.question: You are operating a Commercial Air Transport flight. During pre flight, the latest weather update informs you of a runway change at destination, which leads to a longer arrival procedure. The Trip Fuel

options.text: remains unchanged, as the amount of fuel for arrival is a fixed quantity.
remains unchanged, as it is NOT related to the arrival procedure.
could be updated, but the Contingency Fuel anyway covers changes at the pre flight stage.

options.text: Has a certified take off mass greater or equal to 136 000 kg
Requires a runway length of at least 2 000m at maximum certified take-off mass
Has a certified take-off mass greater than or equal to 140 000 kg
Has a certified landing mass greater than or equal to 136 000 kg

 Today your calculated Take-off Mass is 130 000 kg

Which of the following statements is (are) correct with regard to the operation of flight planning computers?
1) The computer can file the ATC flight plan.
2) In the event of inflight re-routing the computer produces a new plan.

Which of the following statements is (are) correct with regard to the operation of flight planning computers?
 
1) The computer can file the ATC flight plan.
 
2) In the event of inflight re-routing the computer produces a new plan.
The appropriate ATS unit has to be informed in case of inadvertent changes from a Flight plan

options.text: if the average TAS at cruising level varies or is expected to vary by ±5% from that given in the flight plan.
if the time estimate for the next reporting point is found to be in error in excess of more than ten minutes from that notified to ATS.

variant.question: What are the responsibilities of the commander of a commercial air transport flight with regards to fuel in case of diversion

options.text: Remaining fuel should be at least the same as that required to reach an aerodrome or operating site where a safe landing can be made, with final reserve fuel remaining
As a diversion is a spontaneous event, it is a criteria that lies outside the commanders responsibilities with regards to fuel on board
Remaining fuel should be at least the same as that required to return to the aerodrome or operating site of departure
Remaining fuel should be at least the same as that required to reach at least 2 different aerodrome or operating site where a safe landing can be made

The tailwind component will increase by 9 kt.
The new estimated GS will be 71 kt.
The revised flight time will be equal to 16 minutes.

variant.question:
(Refer to the image or Flight Planning Manual MRJT 1 Figure 4.4) 
Planning a flight from Paris Charles de Gaulle to London Heathrow for a twin - jet aeroplane. 
Preplanning:  Dry Operating Mass  DOM: 34 000 kg  Traffic Load: 13 000 kg 
The holding is planned at 1 500 ft above alternate elevation. 
The alternate elevation is 256 ft. The holding is planned for 30 minutes with no reductions. 
Determine the Estimated Landing Mass at alternate Manchester.

For a Commercial Air Transport Aeroplane flight, according to the European Regulations "Air Operations", the operator shall establish a procedure to ensure that in-flight fuel checks and fuel management are carried out, in order: - To determine the expected usable fuel remaining on arrival at the destination aerodrome. - To compare actual consumption with planned consumption. - To ensure dumping of excess fuel during the cruise that may otherwise result in exceeding the maximum landing mass. - To check that usable remaining fuel is sufficient to complete the flight. Select the correct statements.

Provided that the flight is performed as planned, determine the in-flight revised landing mass at the destination, given:
Dry Operating Mass (DOM): 30 510 kgTraffic Load: 8 000 kgRemaining Usable Fuel: 3 788 kgRemaining Trip Fuel: 1 725 kgFinal reserve fuel: 883 kgAlternate fuel: 1 075 kg

Given the following information, calculate the revised estimated Landing Mass at the destination aerodrome.
DOM: 9900 Ib
Traffic Load: 3160 Ib
Remaining Useable Fuel: 2100 Ib
Remaining Trip Fuel to the destination: 800 Ib
Alternate Fuel: 485 Ib
Final Reserve: 420 Ib.
